translated: 5Here is the corrected and aligned text:ğŸ”½MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra, Scroll 89
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order
Chapter 26, Section 5: Practicing PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ, Part One
ÅšÄriputra!

When these bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ, they do not see the arising or cessation of the nose-faculty, nor do they see the arising or cessation of the olfactory-world, olfactory-consciousness, olfactory-contact, or the various feelings produced by olfactory-contact as their condition;

they do not see the grasping or rejection of the nose-faculty, nor do they see the grasping or rejection of the olfactory-world up to the various feelings produced by olfactory-contact as their condition;

they do not see the defilement or purity of the nose-faculty, nor do they see the defilement or purity of the olfactory-world up to the various feelings produced by olfactory-contact as their condition;ğŸ”½they do not see the aggregation or dispersal of the nose-faculty, nor do they see the aggregation or dispersal of the olfactory-world up to the various feelings produced by olfactory-contact as their condition;

they do not see the increase or decrease of the nose-faculty, nor do they see the increase or decrease of the olfactory-world up to the various feelings produced by olfactory-contact as their condition.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the nose sense field is equal to emptiness, non-existent, and cannot be attained.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the arising or cessation of the tongue sense field, nor does he see the arising or cessation of the taste sense field, the tongue consciousness sense field, or the tongue contact or the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact;ğŸ”½he does not see the grasping or rejection of the tongue sense field, nor does he see the grasping or rejection of the taste sense field up to the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact;
he does not see the defilement or purity of the tongue sense field, nor does he see the defilement or purity of the taste sense field up to the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact;

They do not see the tongue element as either coming together or dispersing, and they do not see the taste element, up to the tongue contact that is the support for the arising of sensation as either coming together or dispersing;

they do not see the tongue element as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the taste element, up to the tongue contact that is the support for the arising of sensation as increasing or decreasing.
Why is this?
Because the nature of the tongue element is empty and does not exist, and it cannot be apprehended.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way is able to accomplish omniscience, because he has no learning and no accomplishment as his skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the body element as arising or ceasing, and he does not see the touch element, body consciousness element, and body contact that is the support for the arising of sensation as arising or ceasing;

They do not see the body element as either grasped or abandoned, and they do not see the tactile objects element up to the body contact element and the feelings that arise from the condition of body contact as either grasped or abandoned;

They do not see the body element as either defiled or pure, and they do not see the tactile objects element up to the body contact element and the feelings that arise from the condition of body contact as either defiled or pure;ğŸ”½They do not see the body element as either arising or ceasing, and they do not see the tactile objects element up to the body contact element and the feelings that arise from the condition of body contact as either arising or ceasing;

They do not see the body element as either increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the tactile objects element up to the body contact element and the feelings that arise from the condition of body contact as either increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the body element is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as the skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, does not see the arising or cessation of the mind-consciousness element, does not see the dharma element, mind-consciousness element, or mind-contact and the feelings that arise from mind-contact as a condition;

does not see the grasping or rejection of the mind-consciousness element, does not see the dharma element up to mind-contact and the feelings that arise from mind-contact as a condition as grasping or rejecting;

does not see the defilement or purity of the mind-consciousness element, does not see the dharma element up to mind-contact and the feelings that arise from mind-contact as a condition as defilement or purity;ğŸ”½does not see the accumulation or dispersal of the mind-consciousness element, does not see the dharma element up to mind-contact and the feelings that arise from mind-contact as a condition as accumulation or dispersal;

does not see the increase or decrease of the mind-consciousness element, does not see the dharma element up to mind-contact and the feelings that arise from mind-contact as a condition as increase or decrease.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the mind-consciousness element is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because he takes non-learning and non-accomplishment as his skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the arising or cessation of the earth element, nor does he see the arising or cessation of the water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness elements;
he does not see the acceptance or rejection of the earth element, nor does he see the acceptance or rejection of the water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness elements;
he does not see the defilement or purity of the earth element, nor does he see the defilement or purity of the water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness elements;
he does not see the aggregation or dispersion of the earth element, nor does he see the aggregation or dispersion of the water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness elements;
he does not see the increase or decrease of the earth element, nor does he see the increase or decrease of the water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness elements.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the earth element is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way is able to accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the arising or cessation of the noble truth of suffering, nor does he see the arising or cessation of the noble truths of the origin, cessation, or path;ğŸ”½he does not see the acceptance or abandonment of the noble truth of suffering, nor does he see the acceptance or abandonment of the noble truths of the origin, cessation, or path;ğŸ”½he does not see the defilement or purity of the noble truth of suffering, nor does he see the defilement or purity of the noble truths of the origin, cessation, or path;
he does not see the aggregation or dispersion of the noble truth of suffering, nor does he see the aggregation or dispersion of the noble truths of the origin, cessation, or path;
They do not see the noble truth of suffering increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the noble truths of the arising, cessation, and path increasing or decreasing.
Why is this?
Because the nature of the noble truth of suffering is equal to emptiness, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way is able to accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they do not see ignorance arising or ceasing, and they do not see the formations, consciousness, name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, depression, and anxiety arising or ceasing;

They do not see ignorance as something to grasp or abandon, and they do not see the formations up to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, depression, and anxiety as something to grasp or abandon;

They do not see ignorance as defiled or pure, and they do not see volitional formations up to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and mental anguish as defiled or pure;ğŸ”½They do not see ignorance as compounded or dispersed, and they do not see volitional formations up to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and mental anguish as compounded or dispersed;
They do not see ignorance as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see volitional formations up to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and mental anguish as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of ignorance is equal to emptiness, non-existent, and cannot be attained.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, does not see the arising or cessation of internal emptiness, and does not see the arising or cessation of external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, empty emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, conditioned emptiness, unconditioned emptiness, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, dispersed emptiness, emptiness of change, inherent emptiness, specific emptiness, general emptiness, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-attainment, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, or emptiness of the nature of non-existence.ğŸ”½He does not see the grasping or abandoning of internal emptiness, and does not see the grasping or abandoning of external emptiness up to the emptiness of the nature of non-existence.ğŸ”½He does not see the defilement or purity of internal emptiness, and does not see the defilement or purity of external emptiness up to the emptiness of the nature of non-existence.
He does not see the accumulation or dispersal of internal emptiness, and does not see the accumulation or dispersal of external emptiness up to the emptiness of the nature of non-existence.
They do not see internal emptiness as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see external emptiness up to the emptiness of the essential nature of non-existence as increasing or decreasing.
Why is this?
Because the nature of internal emptiness and so forth is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because it is done by means of not learning and not accomplishing anything.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they do not see the true nature as arising or ceasing, and they do not see the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, unarisen nature, dharma determination, dharma abiding, reality limit, space realm, or inconceivable realm as arising or ceasing;
they do not see the true nature as grasped or abandoned, and they do not see the dharma realm up to the inconceivable realm as grasped or abandoned;

They do not see suchness as defiled or pure, and they do not see the dharma realm up to the inconceivable realm as defiled or pure;ğŸ”½They do not see suchness as accumulated or dispersed, and they do not see the dharma realm up to the inconceivable realm as accumulated or dispersed;
They do not see suchness as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the dharma realm up to the inconceivable realm as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of suchness is equal to emptiness, non-existence, and non-attainment.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they do not see the arising or cessation of the perfection of giving, and they do not see the arising or cessation of the perfections of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, or wisdom;
They do not see the perfection of giving as something to grasp or abandon, and they do not see the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, or wisdom as something to grasp or abandon;

they do not see the perfection of giving as defiled or pure, and they do not see the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, or wisdom as defiled or pure;ğŸ”½they do not see the perfection of giving as compounded or dispersed, and they do not see the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, or wisdom as compounded or dispersed;
they do not see the perfection of giving as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, or wisdom as increasing or decreasing.
Why is this?
Because the nature of the perfection of giving and so forth is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because it is done by means of non-learning and non-accomplishment.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the four meditations as arising or ceasing, nor does he see the four immeasurable [minds] or the four formless [absorptions] as arising or ceasing;

he does not see the four meditations as grasped or abandoned, nor does he see the four immeasurable [minds] or the four formless [absorptions] as grasped or abandoned;ğŸ”½he does not see the four meditations as defiled or pure, nor does he see the four immeasurable [minds] or the four formless [absorptions] as defiled or pure;
he does not see the four meditations as accumulated or dispersed, nor does he see the four immeasurable [minds] or the four formless [absorptions] as accumulated or dispersed;
he does not see the four meditations as increasing or decreasing, nor does he see the four immeasurable [minds] or the four formless [absorptions] as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
because the four formless concentrations are essentially empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because he takes non-learning and non-accomplishment as his skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the eight liberations as arising or ceasing, and he does not see the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, or ten universal bases as arising or ceasing;ğŸ”½he does not see the eight liberations as grasped or abandoned, and he does not see the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, or ten universal bases as grasped or abandoned;ğŸ”½he does not see the eight liberations as defiled or pure, and he does not see the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, or ten universal bases as defiled or pure;
he does not see the eight liberations as accumulated or dispersed, and he does not see the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, or ten universal bases as accumulated or dispersed;

They do not see the eight liberations as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the eight superior [spheres of] perception, the nine successive [meditations], or the ten universal bases as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the eight liberations is the same as emptiness, non-existent, and cannot be attained.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because it is done by means of not learning and not accomplishing anything.

ÅšÄriputra!ğŸ”½When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they do not see the four establishments of mindfulness as arising or ceasing, and they do not see the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, or the eightfold noble path as arising or ceasing;

they do not see the four establishments of mindfulness as grasped or abandoned, and they do not see the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, or the eightfold noble path as grasped or abandoned;

They do not see the four establishments of mindfulness as defiled or pure, and they do not see the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of awakening, or eightfold noble path as defiled or pure;ğŸ”½they do not see the four establishments of mindfulness as arising or ceasing, and they do not see the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of awakening, or eightfold noble path as arising or ceasing;

they do not see the four establishments of mindfulness as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of awakening, or eightfold noble path as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the four establishments of mindfulness is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way is able to accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as the skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, does not see the door of emptiness as arising or ceasing, and does not see the door of signlessness or the door of wishlessness as arising or ceasing;
does not see the door of emptiness as something to be taken up or put down, and does not see the door of signlessness or the door of wishlessness as something to be taken up or put down;

does not see the door of emptiness as defiled or pure, and does not see the door of signlessness or the door of wishlessness as defiled or pure;ğŸ”½does not see the door of emptiness as increasing or decreasing, and does not see the door of signlessness or the door of wishlessness as increasing or decreasing;
does not see the door of emptiness as accumulating or dispersing, and does not see the door of signlessness or the door of wishlessness as accumulating or dispersing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the door of emptiness is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because he takes non-learning and non-accomplishment as his skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!
When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the five eyes as arising or ceasing, and does not see the six supernormal knowledges as arising or ceasing;
he does not see the five eyes as grasped or abandoned, and does not see the six supernormal knowledges as grasped or abandoned;
he does not see the five eyes as defiled or pure, and does not see the six supernormal knowledges as defiled or pure;
he does not see the five eyes as accumulating or dispersing, and does not see the six supernormal knowledges as accumulating or dispersing;
he does not see the five eyes as increasing or decreasing, and does not see the six supernormal knowledges as increasing or decreasing.
Why is this?
Because the nature of the five eyes is equal to emptiness, has no existence, and cannot be attained.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because it is done by means of non-learning and non-accomplishment.

ÅšÄriputra!ğŸ”½When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the ten powers of the Buddha as arising or ceasing, and he does not see the four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, or the eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha as arising or ceasing;ğŸ”½he does not see the ten powers of the Buddha as being grasped or abandoned, and he does not see the four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, or the eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha as being grasped or abandoned;

he does not see the ten powers of the Buddha as defiled or pure, and he does not see the four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, or the eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha as defiled or pure;

They do not see the ten powers of the Buddha as either coming together or dispersing, and they do not see the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, or the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha as either coming together or dispersing;

they do not see the ten powers of the Buddha as either increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, or the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha as either increasing or decreasing.
Why is this?
Because the nature of the ten powers of the Buddha is the same as emptiness, which has nothing and cannot be attained.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way is able to accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they do not see the dharma of non-forgetfulness as arising or ceasing, and they do not see the nature of abiding in abandonment as arising or ceasing;

They do not see the absence of forgetfulness as something to be grasped or abandoned, and they do not see the constant abiding in equanimity as something to be grasped or abandoned;ğŸ”½They do not see the absence of forgetfulness as defiled or pure, and they do not see the constant abiding in equanimity as defiled or pure;
They do not see the absence of forgetfulness as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the constant abiding in equanimity as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the absence of forgetfulness is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, does not see any arising or ceasing of the knowledge of all modes, does not see any arising or ceasing of the knowledge of path aspects or the knowledge of all aspects;
does not see any grasping or abandoning of the knowledge of all modes, does not see any grasping or abandoning of the knowledge of path aspects or the knowledge of all aspects;
does not see any defilement or purity of the knowledge of all modes, does not see any defilement or purity of the knowledge of path aspects or the knowledge of all aspects;
does not see any accumulation or dispersal of the knowledge of all modes, does not see any accumulation or dispersal of the knowledge of path aspects or the knowledge of all aspects;
does not see any increase or decrease of the knowledge of all modes, does not see any increase or decrease of the knowledge of path aspects or the knowledge of all aspects.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the knowledge of all modes is equal to emptiness, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because he takes non-learning and non-accomplishment as his skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!
When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see any dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways arising or ceasing, and he does not see any samÄdhi gateways arising or ceasing;

he does not see any dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways as something to be grasped or abandoned, and he does not see any samÄdhi gateways as something to be grasped or abandoned;ğŸ”½he does not see any dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways as defiled or pure, and he does not see any samÄdhi gateways as defiled or pure;
he does not see any dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways as accumulating or dispersing, and he does not see any samÄdhi gateways as accumulating or dispersing;
he does not see any dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways as increasing or decreasing, and he does not see any samÄdhi gateways as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways is equal to emptiness, non-existence, and non-attainability.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.
ÅšÄriputra!

When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he does not see the stream-enterer as born or extinguished, nor does he see the once-returner, non-returner, or arhat as born or extinguished;ğŸ”½he does not see the stream-enterer as grasped or abandoned, nor does he see the once-returner, non-returner, or arhat as grasped or abandoned;ğŸ”½he does not see the stream-enterer as defiled or pure, nor does he see the once-returner, non-returner, or arhat as defiled or pure;
he does not see the stream-enterer as accumulated or dispersed, nor does he see the once-returner, non-returner, or arhat as accumulated or dispersed;
They do not see the stream-enterers increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the once-returners, non-returners, or arhats increasing or decreasing.
Why is this?
Because the nature of the stream-enterers and so forth is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, using non-learning and non-accomplishment as skillful means.

ÅšÄriputra!ğŸ”½When this bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they do not see the approach to the fruit of stream-entry or the approach to the fruit of once-returning or the approach to the fruit of non-returning or the approach to the fruit of arhatship as arising or ceasing;

they do not see the approach to the fruit of stream-entry or the approach to the fruit of once-returning or the approach to the fruit of non-returning or the approach to the fruit of arhatship as grasped or abandoned;

They do not see the approach to the fruit of stream-entry as defiled or purified, and they do not see the approach to the fruit of once-returning, the approach to the fruit of non-returning, the approach to the fruit of arhatship as defiled or purified;ğŸ”½they do not see the approach to the fruit of stream-entry as collected or scattered, and they do not see the approach to the fruit of once-returning, the approach to the fruit of non-returning, the approach to the fruit of arhatship as collected or scattered;

they do not see the approach to the fruit of stream-entry as increasing or decreasing, and they do not see the approach to the fruit of once-returning, the approach to the fruit of non-returning, the approach to the fruit of arhatship as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the approach to the fruit of stream-entry and so forth is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who studies prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way can accomplish omniscience, because it is done by means of non-learning and non-accomplishment.
ÅšÄriputra!

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, does not see the pratyekabuddha's arising or ceasing, does not see the pratyekabuddha's approach to the pratyekabuddha fruit as arising or ceasing;

does not see the pratyekabuddha as grasping or abandoning, does not see the pratyekabuddha's approach to the pratyekabuddha fruit as grasping or abandoning;ğŸ”½does not see the pratyekabuddha as defiled or pure, does not see the pratyekabuddha's approach to the pratyekabuddha fruit as defiled or pure;
does not see the pratyekabuddha as accumulating or dispersing, does not see the pratyekabuddha's approach to the pratyekabuddha fruit as accumulating or dispersing;
does not see the pratyekabuddha as increasing or decreasing, does not see the pratyekabuddha's approach to the pratyekabuddha fruit as increasing or decreasing.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the pratyekabuddha and so forth is empty, non-existent, and unobtainable.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, by learning prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way, is able to accomplish omniscience, using the method of non-learning and non-accomplishment.
ÅšÄriputra!
This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, does not see the arising or ceasing of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, nor does he see the arising or ceasing of samyak-saá¹ƒbuddhas;
he does not see the grasping or abandoning of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, nor does he see the grasping or abandoning of samyak-saá¹ƒbuddhas;
he does not see the defilement or purity of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, nor does he see the defilement or purity of samyak-saá¹ƒbuddhas;
he does not see the aggregation or dispersion of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, nor does he see the aggregation or dispersion of samyak-saá¹ƒbuddhas;
